memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1468

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general business law, in relation to requiring credit
reporting agencies to furnish proof of identity theft to creditors upon
debtor's request

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
To prevent victims of identity theft from continuing to prove that
such a crime occurred by requiring credit bureaus to keep proof of
such crime and furnish proof upon request.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
This bill adds a new section to Chapter 63, Section 380 of the general
business law.

Section 1 of the bill requires credit reporting agencies to keep all
submitted documentation indicating proof of identity theft for seven
years and to furnish such information to all creditors upon the
request of the victim.

Section 2 of the bill defines proof of identity theft as follows:

a) a copy of a valid police report tiled by the victim alleging the
crime of identity theft;

b) a written statement by the victim claiming to be a victim of
identity theft with respect to the specific debt being collected by
the creditor.

Section 3 of the bill defines a written statement to be as follows:

a) a signed federal trade commission ID theft victim's affidavit;

b) a written statement that certifies to be true under penalty of law
that the victim is a victim of identity theft and did not incur the
debt or authorize the use of the~r name or personal information for
incurring the debt;

Section 3 of the bill requires the following to contain or accompany
the written statement with respect to the relevance of the debt:

a) a copy of the victim's driver's license or state issued
identification card, documentation of the residence of the victim at
the time of the alleged debt; any available correspondence disputing
the debt after transaction information has been provided to the victim;

b) any information concerning who may have incurred the debt such as the
identification of any person who the victim believes is responsible;

c) a telephone number for contacting the victim concerning any
additional information or questions, or direction that further
communicates to the victim be in writing only;

Section 4 defines the written certification as defined in Section 3 to
be sufficient if it is substantially in the following form:

"I certify the representation made are true, correct and contain no
material omissions of fact" Date and Place (Signature)

JUSTIFICATION:
Usually when there has been a case of identity theft, the victim's
personal information is used to open several different accounts.
Those accounts are then utilized and not paid for, eventually ending
up in collections. Collection action can occur immediately or take up
to six and a half years before it is put on the victim's credit
report. While there may be an instance in which the victim has found
out about the debt via letter, phone call or reviewing a copy of
their credit report and has disputed and proven to be a victim,
because of the lag in collections, the information stolen may not get
collected on from another creditor until years later, thereby leaving
the victim to have to prove once again that they have been a victim
of identity theft.

This is an inconvenience for the victim and a burden that they
shouldn't have to sustain as it is not their fault that there is a
lag in collections. This bill would define what proof is needed in
regards to proving identity theft as well as require that once proof
has been established, that the credit bureau must keep the proof for
a period of seven years and furnish it immediately to the credit.or
upon the victim's request.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2009-10: S.2282/A.7181 - REFERRED TO CONSUMER PROTECTION/Referred to
Consumer Affairs and Protection
2008-09: S.8677

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the ninetieth day after it shall have
become law.
